media_caption: Bituing Marikit, 1937 flyer
text_description: Sampaguita Pictures’ inaugural film Bituing Marikit, directed by Carlos Vander Tolosa, is shown. (Photo from Cesar Hernando)

media_caption: Naty Bernardo, Tita Duran, and Rosario Moreno in Octavio Silos’s Tunay na Ina, 1939
text_description: Excelsior’s Tunay na Ina (in photo), directed by Octavio Silos, and LVN’s inaugural film Giliw Ko, directed by Carlos Vander Tolosa, are shown.

media_caption: Liwayway ng Kalayaan, 1944
text_description: Dawn of Freedom (in photo) and Tatlong Maria, Japanese propaganda productions done in cooperation with Filipino filmmakers, are released. (Photo from Cesar Hernando)

media_caption: Facade and reflecting pool of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (Photo by Akio Kawasumi in The Architecture of Leandro
media_credit: Photo by Akio Kawasumi in The Architecture of Leandro V. Locsin by Nicholas Polites. John Weatherhill Inc, 1977
text_description: The Cultural Center of the Philippines is inaugurated. It will have programs for film in later years. (Photo by Akio Kawasumi in The Architecture of Leandro V. Locsin by Nicholas Polites. John Weatherhill Inc, 1977.)

media_caption: Lito Legaspi and Merle Fernandez in Ruben Abalos’s Uhaw, 1970
text_description: Uhaw, the first bomba film, is shown. (Photo from Cesar Hernando)

media_caption: Lilia Dizon, Christopher de Leon, Eddie Garcia, and Lolita Rodriguez in Tinimbang Ka Ngunit Kulang, 1974
text_description: Lino Brocka’s Tinimbang Ka Ngunit Kulang is shown.

media_caption: Mary Walter
media_credit: Photo from Mike de Leon Collection
text_description: The silent movie era flourishes. Silent film actors such as Mary Walter (in photo), Manuel Ramirez, Naty Fernandez, Gregorio Fernandez, and Nora Linda rise to fame. (Photo from Mike de Leon Collection)

media_caption: Lav Diaz’s Norte, Hangganan ng Kasaysayan, 2013
text_description: Lav Diaz’s Norte, Hangganan ng Kasaysayan is screened at the Cannes International Film Festival. It also receives the Nuremberg International Human Rights Film Award. (Photo from Lav Diaz)

media_caption: Dolphy and Niño Muhlach in Ang Tatay Kong Nanay, 1978
text_description: Dolphy posthumously receives the Gawad CCP para sa Sining (Film and Broadcast Arts). (Photo from Mario Hernando)

media_caption: Eugene Domingo in Marlon Rivera’s Ang Babae sa Septic Tank, 2011
article_title: Film 2011 Ang Babae sa Septic Tank
text_description: Ang Babae sa Septic Tank is shown and wins Best Picture at the Cinemalaya Festival. (Photo from Marlon Rivera)

media_caption: Alessandra de Rossi in Busong, 2011
text_description: Busong by Auraeus Solito wins the Emile Cantillon Cinema of Tomorrow Award from the Brussels International Independent Film Festival, and the FIPRESCI Award from the Almaty Eurasia International Film Festival. (Photo from Cinemalaya)

media_caption: John Regala, Jhong Hilario, Maria Isabel Lopez, and Coco Martin in Kinatay, 2009
text_description: Brillante Mendoza wins the Best Director award at the Cannes Film Festival for Kinatay (in photo). (Photo from Brillante Mendoza)

media_caption: Marceliano Ilagan and Atang de la Rama in Jose Nepomuceno’s Dalagang Bukid, 1919
text_description: The popular sarsuwela Dalagang Bukid written by Hermogenes Ilagan and composed by Leon Ignacio is made into a film produced and directed by Jose Nepomuceno, with Atang de la Rama in the title role, performing songs live in some screenings. (Photo from Mowelfund)

media_caption: Julian Manansala’s Patria Amore, 1929
text_description: Julian Manansala directs and produces Patria Amore, a film based on the Philippine Revolution, which angers the Spanish community in the country. (Photo from Cesar Hernando)

media_caption: Noli Me Tangere, 1930 flyer
text_description: The silent movie adaptation of Noli Me Tangere directed by Jose Nepomuceno is shown. (Photo from Nicanor G. Tiongson)

media_caption: Jose Nepomuceno’s Punyal na Ginto, 1933
text_description: Punyal na Ginto, produced by Malayan Movies, the first complete Filipino talking picture, is shown. (Photo from Cesar Hernando)

media_caption: Eduardo de Castro’s Zamboanga, 1937
text_description: Filippine Films’ Zamboanga, directed by Eduardo de Castro, is made for foreign distribution. The film is shown in the US in 1937. (Photo from Martin Magsanoc)

media_caption: Output of the Big Three Studios 1946-1960
media_credit: Photo prepared by Clodualdo del Mundo Jr and designed by Tom Estrera III
text_description: The “Big Four” companies—Sampaguita, LVN, Premiere, and Lebran—produce about 60% of the films in a year. These include dramas, musicals, comedies, horror films, and historical films. (Photo prepared by Clodualdo del Mundo Jr and designed by Tom Estrera III)

media_caption: Tessie Agana and Boy Alano on the right and Van de Leon (between two policemen) on the left, in Olive La Torre’s Roberta, 1951
text_description: Roberta by Sampaguita Pictures is shown. Its box-office success helps Sampaguita to rise from the ashes of a studio fire. (Photo from Cesar Hernando)

media_caption: Jose Padilla Jr, Rita Gomez, and Anita Linda in Sawa sa Lumang Simboryo, 1952
text_description: The Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) is established, replacing the Maria Clara Awards. Among the first winners are Ang Sawa Sa Lumang Simboryo (in photo), Best Picture; Gerardo de Leon, Best Director ( Bagong Umaga ); Alicia Vergel, Best Actress ( Basahang Ginto ); and Ben Perez, Best Actor ( Bagong Umaga ). (Photo from Cesar Hernando)

media_caption: Edna Luna and Jaime de la Rosa in Dyesebel, 1953
text_description: Dyesebel, directed by Gerardo de Leon and based on the Mars Ravelo komiks serial is shown, starring Edna Luna as the titular mermaid. (Photo from Cesar Hernando)

media_caption: Tony Santos, Rosa Rosal, and Vic Bacani in Anak Dalita, 1956
media_credit: Photo from National Library of the Philippines
text_description: Anak Dalita, directed by Lamberto Avellana, is released. (Photo from National Library of the Philippines)

media_caption: Rosa Rosal, Vic Silayan, and Joseph de Cordova in Badjao, 1957
text_description: Lamberto Avellana wins Best Director for Badjao in the Asian Film Festival. FAMAS gives LVN Pictures the International Prestige Award for the success of Badjao. (Photo from Mike de Leon)

media_caption: Leroy Salvador, Rosa Rosal, Marita Zobel, Carlos Padilla Jr, and Danilo Jurado in Biyaya ng Lupa, 1959
text_description: Leroy Salvador wins the Best Supporting Actor award in the Asian Film Festival in Tokyo for Biyaya ng Lupa. (Photo from Mike de Leon)

media_caption: Oscar Keesee and Edita Vital in Noli Me Tangere, 1961
text_description: Gerardo de Leon’s Noli Me Tangere is shown. It wins major FAMAS awards. Photo: Oscar Keesee and Edita Vital in Noli Me Tangere, 1961 (Cesar Hernando Collection)

media_caption: Rosa Rosal, Vic Silayan, and Joseph de Cordova in Badjao, 1957
text_description: Badjao is screened at the Edinburgh Film Festival.

media_caption: Joseph Estrada and Imelda Ilanan in Geron Busabos: Ang Batang Quiapo, 1964
text_description: Geron Busabos by Cesar Gallardo is shown. (Photo from Mowelfund)

media_caption: Pianing Vidal, as Don Lorenzo, surrounded by his “children,” clockwise from right, Daisy Avellana, Sarah K. Joaquin, Naty Crame-Rogers, and Nick Agudo in Lamberto V. Avellana’s A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, 1965
text_description: A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino is screened at the Frankfurt Film Festival. (Photo from Mike de Leon)

media_caption: Bembol Roco and Hilda Koronel in Maynila: Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag, 1975
text_description: Maynila: Sa Mga Kuko ng Liwanag, directed by Lino Brocka, is shown. (Photo from Mike de Leon)

media_caption: Mona Lisa and Hilda Koronel in Insiang, 1976
text_description: Insiang competes at the Cannes Film Festival. (Photo from Cesar Hernando)

media_caption: Insignia of the Order of National Artist, previous, conferred in 1976 on National Artist for Theater and Film Lamberto Avellana
text_description: Lamberto V. Avellana receives the National Artist Award for Theater and Film.

media_caption: Poster of Kidlat Tahimik’s Perfumed Nightmare, 1977
text_description: Mababangong Bangungot (Perfumed Nightmare), directed by Kidlat Tahimik, wins the Prix de la Critique Internationale by the FIPRESCI Jury at the Berlin Film Festival. The director will be regarded later as the “Father of the Indie Film." (Photo from Kidlat de Guia)

media_caption: Bayani Casimiro, Vilma Santos, and Romy Brion in Burlesk Queen, 1977
text_description: Burlesk Queen by Celso Ad. Castillo is shown. The film marks the transition of Vilma Santos from movie star to major actress. (Photo from Cesar Hernando)

media_caption: Daria Ramirez, left, Rustica Carpio, Leticia de Guzman, and, lying down on the mat, Elizabeth Oropesa in Nunal sa Tubig, 1976
text_description: The Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA) is established. First Best Picture is awarded to Nunal sa Tubig. (Photo from Mario Hernando)

media_caption: Phillip Salvador, Menggie Cobarrubias, and Johnny Delgado in Jaguar, 1979
text_description: Jaguar, a film about criminality in the city, competes at the Cannes Film Festival. (Photo from Mario Hernando)

media_caption: Gina Alajar and Dennis Roldan in Salome, 1981
text_description: Salome, directed by Laurice Guillen, is shown. (Photo from Cesar Hernando)

media_caption: Rod Leido, left, Dodo Cabasal, Vic Lima, Noel Trinidad, Mark Gil, Jimmy Javier, Ricky Sandico, Ward Luarca, and Edwin Reyes in Batch ‘81, 1982
text_description: Batch ’81 directed by Mike de Leon, Himala by Ishmael Bernal, and Oro, Plata, Mata (in photo) by Peque Gallaga are shown. Himala and Oro, Plata, Mata are the first two films funded by the ECP. (Photo from Cesar Hernando)

media_caption: Charo Santos and Charito Solis in Kisapmata, 1981
text_description: Kisapmata (in photo) and Batch ’81 are screened during the Directors’ Fortnight at the Cannes Film Festival. (Photo by Cesar Hernando)

media_caption: Mike de Leon's Lakbayan, 1984
text_description: The Makiisa Festival at Fort Santiago showcases anti-Marcos poems, plays, music, and films including Signos and Lakbayan (in photo). (Photo from Mario Hernando)

media_caption: Phillip Salvador, center, carrying RR Herrera in Lino Brocka’s Orapronobis, 1989
text_description: Lino Brocka’s Orapronobis is banned for local screening by the MTRCB for its supposed subversive theme and for being produced by an unregistered foreign production company. The film is eventually screened at the UP Film Center and the Cannes Film Festival. (Photo from Mario Hernando)

media_caption: Nora Aunor and Rita Avila in The Flor Contemplacion Story, 1995
text_description: The Flor Contemplacion Story wins the Golden Pyramid Award for director Joel Lamangan and the Princess Pataten Statue for Best Actress for Nora Aunor in the Cairo International Film Festival. (Photo from Mario Hernando)

media_caption: Jaclyn Jose and Gina Alajar in Mulanay: Sa Pusod ng Paraiso, 1996
text_description: Mulanay directed by Gil Portes wins Best Picture, Best Director, Best Screenplay (Clodualdo del Mundo Jr), Best Actress (Jaclyn Jose), Best Actor (John Arcilla), and Best Musical Score (Joy Marfil) in the Manila Film Festival. (Photo from Mario Hernando)

media_caption: Cesar Montano, center, with Cesar Xerez-Burgos and Jaime Fabregas in Jose Rizal, 1998
text_description: Jose Rizal directed by Marilou Diaz-Abaya is released. Other films celebrating the centennial are Damong Ligaw, Rizal sa Dapitan, and Bayaning 3rd World. (Photo from Mario Hernando)

media_caption: Ricky Davao and Cris Villanueva in Bayaning 3rd World, 1999
text_description: Bayaning 3rd World directed by Mike de Leon is shown. (Photo from Mike de Leon)

media_caption: Jon Red’s Still Lives, 1999
text_description: Digital video technology arrives in Manila. Jon Red directs the first Filipino digital film Still Lives. (Photo from Jon Red)

media_caption: Marcus Madrigal and Ana Capri in Live Show, 2001
text_description: Live Show by Jose Javier Reyes is shown locally with a legitimate MTRCB permit, but is ultimately pulled out of theaters as ordered by Malacañan after conservative sectors condemned the film’s sexual scenes. MTRCB Chairman Nicanor Tiongson resigns in protest. (Photo from Cesar Hernando)

media_caption: Gloria Romero and Jiro Manio in Magnifico, 2003
text_description: Magnifico by Mario J. de los Reyes wins the Crystal Bear and the Deutsches Kinderhilfswerk Grand Prix awards in the Berlin International Film Festival. (Photo from Mario Hernando)

media_caption: Coco Martin in Brillante Mendoza’s Masahista, 2005
text_description: Masahista by Brillante Mendoza wins the Golden Leopard award in the video section of the 2005 Locarno International Film Festival. (Photo from Brillante Mendoza)

media_caption: Gina Pareño in Kubrador, 2006
text_description: Gina Pareño wins the Best Actress Award at the Amiens International Film Festival and at the Brussels International Film Festival for her performance in Kubrador by Jeffrey Jeturian. The film also receives the FIPRESCI Award at the Moscow International Film Festival. (Photo from Jeffrey Jeturian)

media_caption: Coco Martin and Mercedes Cabral in Brillante Mendoza’s Serbis, 2008
text_description: Brillante Mendoza’s Serbis wins the Golden Kinnaree Award in the Bangkok International Film Festival Southeast Asian Competition, and is also nominated for the Palme d’Or in the Cannes Film Festival. (Photo by Benjamin Padero)
